title: riemannian geometry - An explicit (maybe algebraic) isometric embedding of the double torus with constant curvature K = -1
body: The following question is related to this previous question, Canonical immersion of the double torus : Is there any known explicit (maybe algebraic) isometric embedding of a genus 2 surface endowed with a metric of constant curvature K = -1 into a Hilbert space of finite dimension? riemannian-geometry hyperbolic-geometry metric-embeddings Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 31, 2020 at 2:28 asked Jul 30, 2020 at 20:40 Mauro Patrão 31 3 3 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 5 $\begingroup$ Isometric embedding into where? $\endgroup$ Deane Yang –  Deane Yang 2020-07-30 23:23:13 +00:00 Commented Jul 30, 2020 at 23:23 $\begingroup$ Into a Hilbert space of finite dimension. $\endgroup$ Mauro Patrão –  Mauro Patrão 2020-07-31 02:27:31 +00:00 Commented Jul 31, 2020 at 2:27 $\begingroup$ Or, to be more concrete, into $\mathbb{R}^n$ for some $n > 0$? $\endgroup$ Deane Yang –  Deane Yang 2020-07-31 02:51:01 +00:00 Commented Jul 31, 2020 at 2:51 $\begingroup$ Into an R^n with a fixed inner product. $\endgroup$ Mauro Patrão –  Mauro Patrão 2020-07-31 19:12:00 +00:00 Commented Jul 31, 2020 at 19:12 $\begingroup$ I’m pretty sure none is known, and it’s an open question whether any such “explicit” embedding or evening just immersion exists. $\endgroup$ Deane Yang –  Deane Yang 2020-07-31 22:11:35 +00:00 Commented Jul 31, 2020 at 22:11 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
